story: NewsGordon Banks gave touching last gt to charity just two weeks before he diedEXCLUSIVE: The Three Lions hero donated a signed photo of his miracle World Cup save from Pele to auction for Alzheimers research despite battling the final stages of cancerShareCommentsBySimon Wright:,  FEB NewsGordon Banks priceless gt to Alzheimers research just weeks before his death has been revealed "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEngland legend Gordon Banks made a touching last gt to help Alzheimer’s research just two weeks before he died. The World Cup winning goalie was battling the final stages of cancer, but still asked close pal Glyne Wetton round to his home to collect a signed photo of his miracle World Cup save from Pele to auction for the charity. “He was always so generous with his autograph, but that was probably the last thing he signed”, said Glyne, . “It was so typical of Gordon that he was thinking about what he could do for others even when he was struggling so much himself. He was the kindest, most humble man I’ve known.” And it was fitting that the ace goalie’s gt was to a charity battling a disease that struck down so many footballers of his generation – feared to be linked to heading the heavy footballs of the era. Gordon also wrote Glyne a poignant letter three weeks before he died on Tuesday, aged , admitting: “I’ve been having a lot of bad days lately.” Then he bravely added: “I know I’ve just got to get on with it and hope I get back to normal.”   He signed off the note by passing on his best wishes to Glyne and his we, saying: “I hope things go well for you both. Take care and look after yourself.” Former PE teacher Glyne yesterday fought back tears as he revealed the letter’s contents – one of many he shycherishes from the star. The pair met in  when Glyne helped Gordon meet his own boyhood football idol, s Wolverhampton Wanderers goalie Bert Williams. “I was hosting a charity dinner at Molyneux Stadium to raise money for the Alzheimer’s Society,” Glyne recalls. “Bert and I had been friends most of our lives and he was one of the guests. Gordon rang me out of the blue askinghe could come too. “He explained he had been a Wolves fan as a boy and that Bert was the reason he became a goalkeeper.”The meeting led to a deep friendship between all three men, until Bert died in January  aged . “I’ll never forget the moment they met,” says Glyne. “It was wonderfully emotional. They embraced and it seemed neither could find the words they wanted to say. “They did talk goalkeeping though – they both had a pop at Joe Hart, then playing for England, saying they thought he was a bit vulnerable at the near post.”   Gordon also revealed his trademark ritual of marking the middle of his goal with his studs and touching both posts before kick-off was copied from Bert. “They grew very close. I would often collect Gordon from his home and drive him to Bert’s where we would spend hours talking football,” added Glyne, of Brewood, Staffs. “It meant Gordon and I became close friends too. He told me all about winning the World Cup and that Pele save in . His stories were amazing, he told them so well, but he was always so modest. No airs and graces, just a wonderful man. “I knew a few days before he died that he was fading. I was so sad when he finally left us. It feels like I’ve not long lost Bert and now I’ve lost Gordon too. “I like to think they’re together again somewhere, talking goalkeeping.”

title: im celebs harry redknapp gives
story: NewsIm A Celebs Harry Redknapp gives eviction notice to needy tenants for huge property dealEXCLUSIVE:  vulnerable people, who live at the Belgravia hotel in Bournemouth, could be forced on to the streets by May - after the millionaire served them eviction noticesShareCommentsByAlan Selby:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsHarry Redknapp has served an eviction notice to the Belgravia Hotel in Bournemouth in a bid to convert the property into luxury flats "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Millionaire Harry Redknapp has come under fire for leaving  vulnerable bedsit shytenants facing homelessness as his company makes a fortune on a property deal.Their worried landlady called on him to cough up some of his pound, winnings from I’m A Celebrity to save them from a le on the streets. Good Samaritan Wendy Hunt, whorents the property and sub-lets rooms to the destitute at the Belgravia Hotel in Bournemouth, has been served an eviction notice by the former soccer boss. It means she and her tenants must be gone by May  so work can start on converting the building into money-spinning luxury flats.Wendy, , said: “I’ve got  people here. All of them will be homeless . We did try to get Harry to give them something to help them, but that was turned down.“A lot of them are vulnerable. They’ve been here years. I took them without deposits because they were on the streets, so now they won’t have money for a deposit somewhere new. “Can’t he do something with the money he won on I’m a Celebrity  He got a lot for that, on top of the money he’s already got. My poor people have got nothing.”  The revelation comes just weeks after Harry, , was pictured handing the jam roly-poly puddings that he raved about on I’m A Celebrity to rough sleepers. One tenant Joanne White, , said: “We’ve sent Harry letters, and not heard anything back. All we want to know ishe’s actually aware of what this is going to do to us.” Another, Edward Hyde, , added: “We just don’t want to be made shyhomeless. This isn’t a vendetta. It’s not about us against him. He’s got every right to do what he wants to do.” Wendy and husband Gerry have run the Belgravia as homes for vulnerable people with no deposits, references or guarantors since . Their tenants pay just pound a week including bills. Similar accommodation nearby costs more than double – and local homeless services are believed to be full. In , Pierfront Developments – with former West Ham and Spurs manager Redknapp and his we Sandra as directors – bought the property from the owner for pound.million.  The local council turned down plans to demolish the hotel – but it’s set to give the go-ahead on Tuesday to proposals to convert the inside of the building to  flats and build five mews houses on surrounding land. Sub-tenant Edward told us he moved in three and a half years ago after losing his job as a hospital porter. He said he did not qualy for support from Bournemouth Council because he was not a high priority candidate. Wendy and Gerry offered him a room after an outreach worker suggested the Belgravia. He said: “There’s nowhere in this town where you could move in without references, a deposit, and all of that. “You’ve got to be perfect to move in somewhere and be a key holder. You also need shythousands of pounds. “We don’t know how we’re going to raise enough money. We want to know support is going to be there. We want to be resettled. We don’t want to be on the streets.” Trevor Simpson, who moved in after leaving prison, said: “No-one really cares about homeless people. It’s the same across the whole country.  “Wendy will take anyone here. It doesn’t matter who you are, she’ll help youyou help yourself, and give you a roof over your head. “We’ve put objections to the council, but we can’t stop it. All we want is for the council to sit down with Harry, talk things through and let us know where we stand so we can find somewhere to go. “There is nowhere . Even the ASDA car park plays bagpipe music all night to keep people away. Nobody will take anyone without guarantors. Who’s going to guarantee us  “I couldn’t live on the street. It would physically kill me. I know eight people who died last year.” Tenants will be given a month’s notice to leave in writing at the start of April. They can be forgiven for feeling upset by pictures of Harry feeding homeless people at Bournemouth’s Sacred Heart church just a mile and a half away from the Belgravia on December . The star grinned as he said: “It’s all getting eaten.”   Trevor added: “Harry gave out jam roly-poly over Christmas and opened a charity shop the other week. But he’s not come here and spoken to us.” Fellow tenant Joanne said: “I don’t think he’s really taken on board how serious a problem it’s going to be.” Anton Oosthuizen, , who moved in after sleeping rough, said: “We don’t blame him. “We just want some help to find somewhere  to live. We don’t want to stop his venture. We wish him all the best. We’ve sent our letters to him recorded delivery. Why won’t he listen to us ” A design and access statement by a planning consultant hired by Pierfront states the Belgravia “has been converted to provide self-contained bedsit accommodation. The proposals would formalise the existing residential use and ensure a high standard of residential accommodation can be provided.” A letter sent by Pierfront Developments Limited to Wendy and Gerry Hunt in January says: “Please provide confirmation your clients will immediately provide possession on May , .”  Bournemouth Borough Council said: “We would urge all residents who think they are at risk of homelessness to make contact with the council’s Housing Options Team as soon as possible. “Our officers will help them look at rehousing options and make sure they maintain contact with the leaseholder of this property to help enable these timely discussions.” A source told us the application had been delegated to planning officers so, although it has yet to be formally agreed, it was highly unlikely it would be refused. A spokesman for Redknapp’s firm said: “I can confirm Pierfront Developments completed the purchase of the Belgravia Hotel in  with Mr Mrs Hunt being sitting tenants. “Pierfront Developments have a lease in place with Mr and Mrs Hunt, and from Pierfront Developments’ understanding the tenants sub-let the main hotel. “In August  Mr and Mrs Hunt signed a consent order, and notice was served in February to vacate the property by May . All legal proceedings were dealt with by both representatives’ solicitors.”

story: NewsMums joy at finding out shes pregnant after giving birth to stillborn daughter nearly killed herDestiny Young, , was left seriously ill after losing over four pints of blood following an emergency c-sectionShareCommentsByMollie MansfieldNeil Murphy:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMarried couple Destiny, , and Christopher, , Young are filled with joy knowing another baby is on the way "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mother has revealed her joy at becoming pregnant again after giving birth to her stillborn daughter nearly KILLED her.Destiny Young, , almost died after losing almost half the blood in her body during the labour. She was delighted to find out she was pregnant with her first child in January . But after falling unwell and heavily bleeding at just  weeks, Destiny was rushed into surgery for a C-section in in a bid to save her daughter - however, once surgery was over, she was told that her childs heart had stopped beating. The procedure, alongside suffering a ruptured placenta, caused the delivery driver, from Massachusetts, US, to lose over four pints of blood and left her on deaths door for the following six weeks.   However now, Destiny and her husband Christopher, , are filled with joy now they are -weeks pregnant, and are optimistic about the future. Destiny said: When we first tried to get pregnant, we had two miscarriages, but we really wanted a child so continued to try. When we were pregnant with Kaia, everything was looking great and there were no indications that anything was going to go wrong. But then when I reached  weeks, I was really sick so went to the hospital and later on that day I started bleeding so the doctors rushed me to surgery. They gave me a c-section in hope that they would be able to save my babys le, but after the surgery was done they told me her heart had stopped beating. When I had the surgery I lost a lost of blood that it almost killed me - so I was fighting for my le for six weeks while they tried to restore what fluids I had lost.   Dealing with something so physically painful, as well as emotionally, made it the hardest thing I had ever done. But now we have found out we are pregnant again and, although it comes with a lot of fear, we are delighted to hopefully have a healthy baby. Despite Destiny and Christophers excitement at becoming parents again, they are still holding their excitement in until they have confirmation their baby is healthy. Destiny said: For over a year after we lost Kaia I wasnt ready to try again, but we got pregnant right away after deciding we were ready. Were both really excited, but also holding a lot back until we know that shes healthy.   Due to our last pregnancy, I am now being monitored really closely to make sure everything goes well - higher levels of ultrasounds, and being seen at hospital more often. I think until the baby is in my arms and alive, its something that Ill be battling with for the rest of my pregnancy. Destiny is sharing her story to open peoples eyes to why abortion can help people - and even save lives - in light of new abortion laws coming into play in New York, US, which allows women to have abortions after  weeksnecessary to preserve the mothers health orthe fetus isnt viable. She said: If people find out that their children may not make it, or that they are going to have a condition which may cause them to be stillborn, I believe a woman should be entitled to having an abortion.  It is someones own choice, and at the end of the day it could save someone s le and stop them from having to go through something that could kill them. A woman should be able to make her own choiceshe finds out her baby is going to die anyway. The doctors have already recommended to me thatour baby has the same condition as Kaia that we terminate the pregnancy, and I think thats a choice I should be entitled to.

story: NewsThousands could receive up to £k on behalf of dead relatives over pension blunderFamilies are due a windfall after experts reveal they claim compensationthey have been given bad financial adviceShareCommentsByStephen Hayward:,  FEB NewsMore than £million compensation was awarded for missold personal pensions last year and experts believe the figure will higher in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands could receive windfalls of up to pound, on behalf of dead relatives who have been missold personal pensions, say experts. Under a little known rule, families can claim compensationa financial adviser has given bad advice that results in the loss of savings. Finance experts expect a flood of claims after pensions campaigner and independent MP Frank Field revealed the fightback against dodgy advisers can be made by relatives who suspect pension mis-sales. He said: “Another line of defence will be built up against unscrupulous fee-chasing financial advisersmany more people are made aware that justice can reach back from beyond the grave. “These are people’s le’s savings, their lelong plans for their and their family’s last years. In these circumstances, it’s not just the inidual affected by bad advice, but also their partner and dependents.”   More than poundmillion in compensation was awarded for missold personal pensions last year - double the amount paid out in . But experts believe the figure will be even higher this year. Sarah Stokes of Pension Claim Consulting says she has seen a huge spike in compensation cases for pension holders who have died. She said: “More and more people want to claim after a relative or friend has died, usually the deceased had no clue they had been given bad advice. “But when their finances are examined after they’ve passed, it becomes clear they’d been guided into unsuitable pension investments. “Our caseload for such claims is  times what it was a year ago because people are starting to cotton onto the regulations, which have not been very well publicised.   “When you think that over  million people have a personal pension, it stands to reason that claims will continue to rise.” Windfalls often total pound, and can rise to pound,the financial ombudsman upholds a claim. The Financial Conduct Authority imposes a maximum six year year deadline for people to make a claim for a missold pensionan adviser is still trading. But this goes down to three years once the details of the pension investments become known. No time limits are appliedthe adviser has stopped trading.

Writing on Twitter , Mr Dutton said: Signs that impressively warm air is likely to surge towards the UK and Ireland later next week.If it happens, theres a chance that the record for the UKs warmest February daycould be challenged. For context, the same airmass in summer would give temps around -C! In another tweet, he described reports of snow and a big freeze as utter garbage. The current Met Office five day forecast for the country is a mixed bag, with sunshine expected Sunday but blustering showers in the evening and into next week.And yesterday, Met Office forecaster Richard Miles warned more snow could be on the way - by the end of February at least.He said: We could well see some snow by the end of February. title: couple proudly show giant cabbage
story: NewsCouple proudly show off their giant cabbage which is the same size as a personRosemary Norwood and her husband Sean Cadman, who live in Australia, have been growing the cabbage at the bottom of their gardenShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsRosemary Norwood with her giant cabbage "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRosemary Norwood and her husband Sean Cadman have spent the last nine months lovingly taking care of a cabbage growing at the bottom of their garden. And all their hard work has paid off, as they have managed to produce a giant cabbage which is now the same size as a person. The semi-retired couple have been growing vegetables for years but said this is the biggest theyve ever had. Rosemary, , said: Its unbelievable how big it had gotten. I didnt realise just the size of it until we picked it. We had a few cabbages that we had started growing altogether, but the others did not do as well as this one. So, we decided to just let it keep going.   It could have kept growing I think, but we decided we should finally pick it because the insects were starting to get into it. It would have been too dficult to get them out, and we would have ruined it. So it was just time. I had no idea it was that big. My first reaction was to get a photo, because no one would have believed how huge it was. I also use a complete organic fertiliser, which I think really helps.   The couple, who live in Tasmania in Australia, explained they managed to keep out hungry wallabies and possums with a wire fortress fence and had to place the cabbage under a net to stop insects such as slugs and butterflies from getting into it. Rosemary and Sean began growing the cabbage in April last year and finally decided to pick it last month - but admitted they did not realise how large it truly was until it was harvested. And since then, the proud couple have managed to get an incredible three weeks worth of meals out of the cabbage - with both them and their guests enjoying a delicious stream of salads, coleslaw, and German rotkohl.   Rosemary said: Cabbages have always grown well in Tasmania, and this is a testament to that. I think it also has something to do with the weather and the soil fertility. We had a wet spring, good rainfall and hot weather this summer. The cabbage has fed us all really well for the last three weeks, and it still tastes fresh.   We grow as many vegetables as we can for our guests here. We cook dinner most evenings, so we like having lots of fresh produce. Everyone has loved eating the cabbage, and weve tried to be as creative as we can. Thankfully we love cabbage, so its certainly been a real treat.

title: ghost ships spooky sos call
story: NewsGhost ships spooky SOS call before crew found dead with faces frozen in fearThe ship was said to have sent an eerie distress call while sailing the Strait of Malacca - where Malaysia Airlines flight MH vanished in ShareCommentsByCharlotte Neal:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe SS Ourang Medan was found with the entire crew dead and their faces frozen in fear in one of the worlds greatest maritime mysteries"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA spooky SOS call from on board a ship where the entire crew was found dead and frozen in fear has been revealed in a chilling secret memo as the maritime mystery continues to baffle the world. The entire crew of the SS Ourang Medan and its captain were found strewn around the ship with expressions of convulsive horror but no obvious injuries that could have killed them.Before investigations could determine what happened, a fire broke out and the vessel sunk without trace, reports the Sun.A secret CIA memo detailed the eerie frenzied SOS call from on board. All officers, including captain dead, lying in chartroom and on bridge... probably whole crew dead, the call said.   Written by C.H Marck Jr, assistant to the Director of the CIA Allen Dulles, in , to an unknown recipient, the memo continues: There followed a series of indecipherable dots and dashes and then came quite clearly: I die. The document reveals that the agency believed the doomed boat could hold the key to a series of other disappearances in one of the worlds busiest shipping lanes.It was penned years after the dutch vessel is said to have sent a distress call in  while sailing the Strait of Malacca - where Malaysia Airlines flight MH vanished in .The distressing Morse code SOS call, made by a signaller on board SS Ourang Medan, was heard by the crew of nearby ship the Silver Star. Rescue ships rushed to find the stricken vessel, finding her just  miles from the position given. But investigators found an eerie sight when they boarded, the memo continues.  There wasnt a living creature on the ship, it said. The captain lay dead on the bridge. The bodies of the other officers sprawled in the wheelhouse, chartroom and wardroom. The faithful sparks was slumped in a chair in the radio shack, his hand still on the sending key. The bodies of the crew lay everywhere, in the rooms, in the passageways, on the decks. And on all the dead faces was a look of convulsive horror. Referencing a report by Merchant Marine Council, C.H Marck Jr added that their frozen faces were upturned to the sun with mouths open and staring eyes. The ships dog, a small terrier, was also dead with its teeth bared in anger or agony.   The boarding parties decided to tow the vessel to port to continue investigations, but, according to the memo, at that very moment smoke and flames belched forth from the hold. They abandoned the ship and there was an explosion, before it sunk without trace with all the dead crew, never to be seen again. Strangely, the coast guard didnt report it until  - six years after it sank. Some questionit ever existed, with no mention in the Lloyds List of shipping and no record of the Silver Star attempting a rescue. Conspiracy theorists questionseveral countries worked together to cover the mysterious incident up, while others believe a noxious gas bubbled from the seabed. The secret CIA document, released to the public in , questioned whether an unknown entity was to blame. I feel sure that the SS Ourang Medan holds the answer to many of these aeroplane accidents and unsolved mysteries of the sea, the author wrote, pondering the mysteries of the stretch of sea home to many shipwrecks.

title: meet new el chapo
story: NewsMeet the new El Chapo – an evil billionaire ex-cop running worlds worst drug cartelEXCLUSIVE: Despite once being in the police, El Mencho is infamous for his sadistic crimes and has more power than everShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA billionaire ex-cop dubbed El Mencho is now said to be filling the shoes of El Chapo "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJust when you get one notorious drugs lord banged up, along comes one El of a murderous shysuccessor ready to take his place. As Mexican cocaine king Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman begins a le sentence, America’s Drugs Enforcement Administration must now hunt down an even more fearsome quarry. A cunning billionaire former avocado grower and cock-fighting enthusiast — who was once a COP. Nemesio Oseguera-Cervantes — aka El Mencho — is so fearless he even kidnapped the millionaire playboy sons of his now caged arch-rival. After setting up his own New Generation cartel in Jalisco state ten years ago, he made his mark in the bloodcurdling Narcos world by dumping  bound and tortured bodies in the streets of Mexican port Veracruz at rush hour.   Two years later, Mencho’s men raped, killed and set fire to a ten-year-old girl they mistakenly believed to be the daughter of one of their rivals. In , his assassins executed a man and his young son by detonating sticks of dynamite duct-taped to their bodies. Chapo’s partner Ismael “El Mayo” Zambada holds the title of the planet’s biggest drug dealer.But it is little wonder that Oseguera-Cervantes, , is the DEA’s most wanted, with a million bounty on his head.  His crystal meth, cocaine and heroin consignments not only flood the States, but they also hit the streets HERE and in Europe, Australasia, Africa and Asia too. “He’s public enemy number one,” said Paul Craine, who was head of the federal DEA in Mexico during the  arrest of Chapo. “And he’s got an army of thousands of bad guys.”   Chapo, , ran the feared Sinaloa state cartel and was immortalised in the Netflix series Narcos: Mexico. He was caught in  and finally sentenced last week. After his arrest, rival drug dealers shyfought a vicious battle with each other to fill the power vacuum. Chapo’s sons Ivan, , and Guzman,  — kidnapped at a restaurant by Mencho’s men in  and freed after Chapo coughed up an estimated million — were muscled out of the way for partner Mayo to take charge. But as a reclusive diabetic close to , his hold on the cartel is slipping. And while he is seen as a survivor of the old school drug runners who abide by mafia-like codes, former policeman Mencho is the image of the new Mexican cartel don.   His cartel embraces social media as a way to announce their presence – carrying out narco-terrorist attacks, beheadings and the dismembering of bodies, for the world to see. All the time Mencho stays in the shadows. He doesn’t make the kind of public challenges to shyauthority that have led to the downfall of other narcos including Colombia’s Pablo Escobar over the years. And he never, ever touches a phone. His foot soldiers keep order with assault rles and wear a unorm of black balaclavas and T-shirts shyemblazoned with the cartel logo. “He runs his cartel like a paramilitary,” says narcos expert Daniel Solis. “Its arsenal, and its organisation put the regular army to shame. “With the insight he gained while in the police, Mencho knows the power of a well-structured force. He has publicly stated he will die shyfighting rather than be taken alive. He expects the same of all his men.”  Mencho rose to infamy from humble beginnings. He dropped out of school at the age of ten to work on his family’s small avocado farm. Four years later he got a job guarding a weed crop before shysneaking into Calornia and setting up as a small-time dealer. He and his cousin were caught shytrafficking and he was deported in the early s. But on histo Mexico, he shymanaged to hide his criminal past and landed a job with the Jalisco state police. He left for the Millennium Cartel, an old ally of Chapo’s mob, then set up his own firm a decade ago which swtly became known for its horrying mass murders. “Its method of shykilling is more akin to ISIS than the shycartels,” adds Solis. “Never shybefore has how they kill, in the numbers that they kill, been seen in Mexico.” When Mencho is cornered he shydisplays his most barbaric streak.   On May , , the Mexican army planned to strike back at him with Operation Jalisco. In a pre-dawn raid, elite paratroopers and federal shypolice flown in by two military helicopters descended on a ranch where they believed Mencho was hiding. But the cartel was waiting in armoured trucks. One of the helicopters was hit, sending it crashing down in flames. Eight soldiers and a police officer were killed. Hours later, Mencho ordered his men to set fire to dozens of hijacked cars, buses, trucks, petrol stations and banks — gridlocking traffic and bringing Jalisco to its knees. The Mexican government was forced to send in , troops to secure the state. Now, in the wake of Chapo’s jailing, the DEA and Mexican authorities are strengthening their bid to bring Mencho down. If he were shycaptured tomorrow, US authorities would be expected to request his extradition, as they did with Chapo. But one DEA source doubts it will get that far. “Mencho’s such a killer, I’d be surprisedhe was captured alive,” he said.

title: dundee move was easy decision for aberdeens scott wright to make
story: Leaving a squad challenging at the top of the table for one struggling at the bottom may seem like a big decision for any young footballer to make.One that you might need a bit of time to think over.For Dundee’s on-loan winger Scott Wright, however, a phone call to Dens Park boss Jim McIntyre was all it took to convince him to head down from Aberdeen.And just two games into his temporary switch to dark blue, the Scotland U  international is already convinced his snap decision was the right one.“I’m loving it here and all the boys are making me feel really welcome. Now it’s a question of getting settled in as quick as I can and just playing football,” he said.“I had obviously spoken to Derek McInnes and he said to speak to Jim McIntyre before making any decision.“The gaffer at Aberdeen left it up to me.“He told me he’d love to have me still up there butI wanted to go and get games he understood.“So I spoke to the gaffer here on the phone and I loved everything he had to say. I jumped at the chance to come down here.”And the -year-old sees the draws against Hamilton and Kilmarnock since he arrived as proof this is a squad that can pull away from the relegation zone between now and the end of the season.“The only frustrating thing for me so far is that we’ve not taken six points out of six from the two games I’ve been involved in but I think all the fans and us as a team can feel from those performances that we are building momentum.“In the Hamilton game it was a case of everyone trying to get used to each other. A lot of us had only come in right before the deadline and we only really had one training session together.“It was about trying to get to know everyone’s games, their personalities. I think we are all starting to gel now and you can see that on the pitch.“Not having a game last weekend because we’re out of the cup has given us a bit more time to work on that. That gives us a better picture going into the game against Livingston this weekend.”Today’s trip to the Tony Macaroni Arena to face Livingston is a meeting with a team who have taken the Premiership by storm this term but have been struggling for a win of late.Since thumping Hearts - in mid-December, Gary Holt’s team have not won in eight outings. Wright does not see that as a sign this could be an easy  minutes for Dundee.“We have to treat it that every game from now on is going to be a big game for us and this will be.“We know how Livi will be and they will work hard but all we can do is just prepare the way we want to and work on how we can play. Hopefully, that will be enough.“They haven’t won in a few games but it’s a testimony to Livi how many points they have. They started the season so well.”Today, of course, will see Dundee asked to play on Livi’s much-criticised plastic pitch.The debate over their use has surfaced again this week via the PFA canvassing their members for views on them. While Wright is very much in the camp that prefers grass surfaces, the articial surface is not something he’s going to gripe about.“All we can do is get on with it and we are not going to use the pitch as an excuse,” he added.“Playing in Scotland, you get used to them.“However, I think having everyone playing on grass is something that would benefit the top league.“You prepare for a team each week but, for these games, you also have to prepare for the pitch as well.“All we can do as players is give our opinion about them.”

title: gomis set to take over as dundee united target hat trick of wins down at queen of the south
story: Veteran Morgaro Gomis is set to take over in midfield when Dundee United try to make it three wins on the bounce as they head for Queen of the South today.The -year-old is expected to replace Calum Butcher, who will serve the first game of a two-match ban after his red card in the Scottish Cup win at St Mirren last weekend.His second game on the sidelines will be the cup quarter-final against Ross County or Inverness Caley Thistle which has been confirmed for Sunday, March  at pm.The game is also being televised live on BBC Scotland.As well as continuing their recent winning run, the Tangerines will be looking for their third success of the campaign over Queens.To do that, though, manager Robbie Neilson is well aware they will have to keep in-form home striker Stephen Dobbie quiet.His spectacular strike in the cup at Aberdeen on Sunday was the -year-old’s th goal in just  appearances this term.“He has been on fire lately and someone we will have to get to grips with,” said Robbie.“He has a lot of quality, he knows how to score goals.“He’s just a very good player and I think he has the freedom of Dumfries these days. He’s a god down there.”United have their own in-form attacker in the shape of Pavol Safranko.The Slovakian, who’s on loan from Aalborg, has hit the net three times in his last four games.That’s taken his tally so far to  goals and he’s scored on the two previous occasions he’s faced the Doonhamers.“We been playing well and we’re looking for that to continue,” added Robbie.

title: legend maurice malpas reckons january business could help dundee united reach premiership
story: With a total of  appearances for Dundee United, there’s not many better qualied to speak on the state of things at Tannadice than Maurice Malpas.And the club legend reckons their January business has given them “a chance” of promotion back to the Premiership –they can keep displays up for more than  minutes.He said: “The last couple of games they’ve been good in the first half but ran out of steam in the second. If they can get the players bang at it for more of the game I think you have to say they have a chance.“There is a bigger iety of player to choose from now and they have some players who are willing to put a boot in, which you need when games aren’t going your way.“They have a chance of getting up but they can’t drop many points.”As for his own situation, Malpas is quite content looking on from the stands after being assistant to Richie Foran at Inverness last season.Malpas added: “These days I watch United on a Saturday and do a bit of babysitting.“I’ve no desperation to get back in. If something came along I’d consider it but when you’ve been in the game as long as I have you can’t see the wood for the trees. Once you’re out you see the things that really matter in le and I’m quite happy.“I do a bit of coaching over in America a few times a year which gives me my wee fix but I’m quite happy where I am.”

title: livingston may be off form but dundee boss jim mcintyre expects a tough test today
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is taking nothing for granted when his improving team face off-form Livingston at the Tony Macaroni Arena today.The Dark Blues head over the Forth on the back of displays against Hamilton and Kilmarnock that, but for injury time mishaps, would have earned six points instead of two.An injury-time equaliser cost victory at Accies while the chance to take maximum points against Killie last week slipped away when Kenny Miller’s penalty was saved in the fth minute of time added on.Now it’s on to Livi, who’ve not won since before the winter break but Jim believes Gary Holt’s team remain formidable opponents.“It’s natural that at some stage of a season you will have a dip and they’ve still had a brilliant season. They have some very good players,” he said.“The first thing we have to do is try to win our battles but don’t forget they have scored some quality goals, some good team goals.“We have to try to make sure inidually we get the better of them and try to go and create opportunities to win the game.”Dundee go into the clash with controversy over plastic pitches like Livi’s rekindled by a PFA survey showing top-flight players are unied in opposition to them.The manager is also in that camp but hasn’t forgotten that defeat at the Tony Macaroni in his first game in charge was down to what happened in the air and not the surface.That day back in October his team conceded four goals from set pieces.“We didn’t deal with set plays and that killed us. It was an eye-opener that day in terms of what we had to work with,” he said.“There’s no doubt, though, the surface is an advantage. I was the manager of a team, Queen of the South, who had an articial surface andyou train on it every day it’s a definite help.“At the same time I’m not trying to detract from how well Livingston have done because they’ve done exceptionally well.”Dundee are still nursing a few niggling injuries from that Killie draw, but it’s hoped everyone who was on duty then will be available. Midfielder Ethan Robson is expected to recover in time from the groin injury that forced him to miss that game.

title: party goers turning dundee street into bottle graveyard
story: Locals fear streets around one of Dundee’s busiest nightle spots are turning into a “bottle graveyard”.Areas around South Ward Road have been left in a mess in recent months, with revellers knocking back booze on the streets and using electrical boxes as tables before moving on to city nightspots.Pictures taken earlier this week show beer cans and bottles of spirits dumped opposite the petrol station.One local said the area was particularly bad yesterday morning after party-goers had been out on the town.He said: “I came down Thursday morning just before am.“I was greeted with sick, urine, bottles of spirits and empty cans of beer.“It always seems to be worse on a Thursday morning after a Wednesday evening.“It’s a bottle graveyard on the way into work.“I would assume most of the revellers are partaking in student nights out and are trying to save themselves a few quid.“I feel sorry for the street sweepers who need to clean these areas up because it’s a total disgrace.“This isn’t a one-off either as it’s happening every week.“I came down today and it was totally clear, which leads me to believe it’s a problem related to Wednesday nights.”Despite the worries of residents, owners of nightclubs in the area have denied any knowledge of their customers drinking in the streets before entering their premises.The owner of Carbon and Kush nightclub on South Ward Road, Tahir Ramzan, said he was unaware of issues of alcohol being consumed on the surrounding streets.He said: “This is the first I’ve heard about this.“Anything that happens en route to the club is outwith our control.“The problem isn’t directly outside the clubs and might be impacting more on the petrol garage.“We certainly don’t have issues with our customers who come in during the week. They come and enjoy themselves.“Given it is not happening directly outside the club it’s outwith our control.”A spokesman for Club Tropicana and Aura next door urged customers and residents to get in touchthere were any further issues.He said: “We haven’t received any complaints regarding this matter. However, we will investigate with the information you have provided us with.“If anyone would like to get in touch with us simply email info@auradundee.”Dundee City Council had not responded to a request for comment at the time of going to press.

title: young women urged to attend voting event run by dundee womens festival
story: Organisers of a centenary suffrage conference have urged young women to turn out in their droves.Dundee Women’s Festival will run the event on Saturday March  entitled “Why Should I Bother to Vote ” and is stressing that it is aimed at the - age group.Chairwoman Prue Watson, , said: “We want younger people to come along instead of people my age.“They are the future and we also want to encourage them to vote because people have died in the past fighting for this right.“I would tell young women that it is important to vote, you can change things by voting.“We are hoping to have  young people at the event but so far we have only got  registered so there is a real push on to encourage more.“The Scottish Parliament centenary grant has allowed us to host a conference on the fight for women’s suffrage and what our vote means today.“Sofriends, daughters or granddaughters are aged between  and , then sign up and find out.“We will encourage them by looking at the history of women’s suffrage and our political system“There are a lot of very interesting speakers lined up including the author Ajay Close, who is a great writer.“I am sure the women who turn up will be very interested in her talk about suffragettes and what they did in Scotland.“Many suffered terrible forced feeding in Perth prison.”Ms Watson added: “We were awarded £, by the Scottish Parliament to stage the event and it allows us to accommodate  people at the conference which is being held at Dundee and Angus College’s Gardyne Campus.“The event is free and lunch is provided, plus there are workshops in the afternoon.“I am sure it will be a popular day.”The event starts at .am.

title: Autistic boy leads the way in inpsiring kindness project
story: GABRIEL Erasmusrsquos parents have always believed his superpower was his love for people.The -year-old ndash who is autistic, has dyslexia and learning dficulties ndash was unable to speak until he was five.But he was so fascinated with faces he would smile when touching them.And his proud mum Victoria says he has developed an uncanny ability to feel and absorb the emotional discomfort of others.This desire to help gets his creative impulses flowing.His latest venture, inspired by his sadness for an orphan boy he has come to know in his father Jonrsquos South African homeland, has started a kindness craze.His idea to reach out to this boy with a card to cheer him up has inspired hundreds of pupils to join in.Mrs Erasmus, a hotelier whose portfolio includes the Invernessrsquos Glen Mhor Hotel, said for years the family has been helping orphaned children in South Africarsquos Kwa Zulu region.Four years ago they founded the South African Childrenrsquos Charitable Trust and have visited the area with their four children.Mrs Erasmus said: ldquoGabriel came home from school upset one day. His head teacher had been talking about how to build up resilience.ldquoGabriel told him when he has a bad day, I make him feel better, but his -year-old friend at Ikhethelo lsquodoesnrsquot have a mummy to make him feel betterrsquo.Gabriel started to ldquopanic asking how orphaned children could learn resilience or even know they were loved.Mrs Erasmus said: ldquoBefore I could answer, he was asking for a paper and pen to write a card to tell the boy he was special, that he could get through anything and that Gabriel loved him.ldquoThe irony here is that Gabriel cannot write or read and yet he was doing the only thing he could think of to help. He was prepared to work out how to make  cards for the  children at Ikhethelo.Working with printers the youngster created three cards for his pals at the childrenrsquos villages.And the scheme has grown from there.The family split their time between Inverness and Edinburgh, where Gabriel goes to school and gets one-to-one support for his complex needs.Pupils in two Edinburgh schools, as well as those at Cannich Bridge Primary, are now sending cards to the South African youngsters ndash and receiving replies.Posting costs are met by the Erasmusrsquos charity.Amanda Graham, head teacher at Cannich Bridge Primary, said: ldquoIt makes the children in-volved think about others which is really important.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Cycle ride aims to help Highlands special needs charity
story: SUPPORTERS of a leline service for children and young adults with special needs are to take part in a sponsored cycle ride to raise desperately-needed funds.The Special Needs Action Projectis facing an uncertain future after Highland Council turned down the charityrsquos annual grant of pound, ndash  per cent of the total running costs of pound,.After hearing the charity might have to close, two members of Snaprsquos youth club decided to do something to help.Dean Stewart and Bradley Morrall, both aged , suggested a fundraiser and as a result, a sponsored cycle ride will be held on Saturday March  at the Highland Cycle Ability Centre at Cantraybridge.They and others aim to cycle  km by completing laps of the track.Deanrsquos mother Carol Macdonald said her son had attended Snap for many years.ldquoIt has enabled and encouraged him and many others to enjoy le, have fun, learn, grow and flourish with many dferent challenges, she said.ldquoSnap is a much-needed leline for children and young adults, families, siblings and carers.ldquoSnap is like a great big hug. title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Date finally set for demolition of eyesore Eastgate Hostel in Inverness
story: WORK is finally set to start on tackling the fire-ravaged Eastgate Hostel in Inverness ndash almost SIX years after the blaze.A start date of March  has been set to begin the demolition of the High Street building which has been shrouded in scaffolding to the frustration of nearby businesses and community leaders for years.The announcement follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which has kept up the pressure in calling for action and ensuring the issue has remained in the headlines ndash and not forgotten.A spokesman for the owners said following successful negotiations with a demolition contractor the work would begin to take down the frontage of the building and remove the fire-damaged interiors.It is expected to take up to  weeks.Work would start five years and  months after the blaze in April .Community and business leaders have welcomed the news.Crown and City Centre Community Council chairwoman Pat Hayden welcomed the announcement but wondered why work had not started in mid January as previously expected.ldquoI am sorry to say I will only believe it when the workmen are on site, ldquo said Mrs Hayden who congratulated the Inverness Courier for keeping up the pressure since the building was damaged in April .Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoThis is a key city centre location which has for too long been blighted by scaffolding .ldquoThe reinstatement of the High Street is a signicant improvement and I welcome the commitment made by the owners to invest in this key site,she said.Central ward councillor Bet McAllister said it would especially help businesses in the High Street.ldquoI am also heartened to hear of the ongoing commitment to ensure that a replacement building is constructed at the earliest opportunity, she said.But chiropodist Jim Crawford whose business is nearby remained unconvinced. ldquoThere have been so many  dawns, he said. ldquoIf it doesnrsquot start by March , the council should take it over.A spokesman for the buildingrsquos owners said specialist contractors will initially remove asbestos from the site before the scaffolding is removed.The plan is that each stone for the front will be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.The spokesman said the current contract is for the demolition to facilitate the removal of the scaffolding, but the intention was to rebuild fairly soon afterwards.Sunday  Feb  : AM

title: Help for new Highland business talent
story: YOUNG business leaders in the Highlands are being offered a chance to join a highly personalised business growth programme to help drive their businesses forward.IMPACT organised by Highlands and Islands EnterprisersquosNorthern Innovation Hub, in partnership with consultancy business Anderson Anderson and Brown , is now offering  businesses an opportunity to engage in this first of its kind support programme.Julie Lat, of the House of Spice in Fort Augustus, was part of the year-long fully funded programmersquos first intake in November.She said: ldquoI have found IMPACT highly beneficial. title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Sunday  Feb  : AM

story: ABERDEEN suffered a damaging - draw with the Premiership#s bottom side St Mirren at Pittodrie in a match also marred by an injury to defender Tommie Hoban.Dropping points at home to the team rock bottom of the table will be hammer blow to their chances of overtaking second placed Rangers in the Premiership.The only positive, albeit minor, is that the Dons did not lose ground on Rangers who were held - by St Johnstone.A dismal day for the Reds was made even worse when on loan Watford defender Hoban was stretchered off with a knee injury late in the first half.Aberdeen fell behind to Hladky raced off his line to win the ball in a - but Stewart was left poleaxed inside the box as play raged on.Eventually Buddies kicked the ball out to allow Stewart to receive treatment.Aberdeen equalized in the nd minute when a corner from Mackay-Steven was flicked on by Mikey Devlin to the back post.Teenager FERGUSON had drted in unchecked and clinically headed home from eight yards.The Reds should have gone ahead moments later when Stewart squared a pass to McGinn but with the goal beckoning he scooped a shot over from  yards.Aberdeen suffered an injury set-back in the rd minute when on loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban was stretchered off with a knee injury.The defender went down when his studs looked to have caught in the surface going for the ball in front of the Main Stand.There was no contact with a St Mirren player as he appeared to twist awkwardly.Clearly in distress Hoban received treatment on the pitch before being stretchered off.It was the latest injury ligament injury that required surgery.St Mirren should have gone ahead soon after the break when Kyle McAllister#s cross from the right found Brad Lyons unmarked  yards out but his header flashed inches wide of the near post.Slack play when trying to move the ball out of defence was punished by St Mirren in the st minute when a loose pass was intercepted.Buddies raced up field and Lyons found McALLISTER who fired a magnicent,  unstoppable shot from just inside the penalty box into the far corner beyond Joe Lewis.The Reds drew level  in the th minute when COSGROVE met a cross from the left the th minute but referee Craig Thomson waved play on.Moments later Cosgrove should have put the Dons ahead when he met a Stewart cross in a great position only to fire an effort wide.ABERDEEN: Lewis, title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: rest and be thankful mitigation project moves to next phase
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe next phase of the works to form landslide mitigation catch-pits next to the A at the Rest and Be Thankful is now underway.The £.M project started in spring  with works now continuing with the construction of the fourth catch-pit next to the road side.  These landslide mitigation measures involve the excavation of debris flow catch-pits next to the A.The catch-pits are designed to stop debris reaching the road from a landslide down the channels above each catch-pit location, helping to keep the A open.  Once completed, this fourth catch-pit will provide an additional , tonnes of debris storage capacity, bringing the total volume protection of the catch-pits to approximately , tonnes.In addition to the catch-pits, works on the additional protection measures at Glen Kinglas, approximately three miles from the Rest and Be Thankful, will continue.  The works at Glen Kinglas involve the re-use of the excavated rock from the Rest and be Thankful to form landslip mitigation bunds above streams along Glen Kinglas. The bunds will help reduce the risk of debris reaching the A in the event of a landslide.This project allows BEAR Scotland to maximise the benefit of recycling the material being excavated from the Rest and Be Thankful while minimising the overall cost of these works.To keep roadworkers and motorists safe throughout the works, temporary traffic lights will be in place on the A at each location. This next phase of the works is expected to last approximately  weeks.Commenting on the works, Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland’s North West Representative said: #The installation of the next stages of the mitigation measures will provide more protection and resilience against any future landslips blocking this key route at both the Rest and Be Thankful and Glen Kinglas.#The temporary traffic lights are necessary to keep our teams as well as users of the route safe during the works, and the teams will do all they can to complete the project as quickly and safely as possible.#We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date travel information.#

title: human rights monitor philppa bonella speaks at ms centre
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowSt Margaret’s Justice and Peace Group invited Philppa Bonella to Lochgilphead on Tuesday February  to talk about her experiences as a human rights monitor on the Ecumenical Accompaniment Programme in Palestine and Israel .She was in the Holy Land for three months last year and spent time on the West Bank in Palestinian villages surrounded by Israeli settlements.Philippa told her audience that the EAPPI sends batches of people of all nationalities to the Holy Land for these three-month stints, where the monitors are split into small groups and must operate in pairs for safety.She recalled particular incidents – schools tear-gassed by Israeli troops, homes searched in raids during the middle of the night, families prevented from picking their olives, Palestinian villages surrounded by Israelis in mobile homes, supported by Israeli government-funded water and electricity supplies.Human rights monitors must be impartial and Philippa did her utmost to present a balanced picture and all EAPPI monitors share their findings and experiences with the UN with the intention of furthering solutions in this troubled region. Her conclusions drawn from experience was that when the monitors were around, there may have been unpleasant situations, but no tragedies. When there was no monitor around – clearly defined by their unorms – people died.Philippa had only been home for eight weeks when she spoke to the Justice and Peace Group, and she admitted that she was still processing the often brutal and violent scenes she had witnessed. And though she wryly joked that it had not exactly been a picnic, she encouraged her audience to become involved in the work of EAPPI – through prayer, support, even by volunteering to be a monitor .For more information, visit eappi.org en or visit the EAPPI Facebook page @EAPPI.WCCPIC:Her stories of the hardships in Israel kept visitors engaged. no_aholylandPhillipa Bonella speaking at the MS Centre. no_aholyland

story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback.
